abstract.p: New Jersey state auditor Richard Fair reports that state has spent $3.6 million extra on alternative-fuel vehicles without any environmental benefit due to lack of availability of compressed natural gas (S)

block.p: Meeting state and federal requirements to buy vehicles that do not burn gasoline, New Jersey has bought 1,100 vehicles that can be fueled with compressed natural gas. But most of them have never been run on anything other than gasoline, said Richard L. Fair, the state auditor, in a report released last week. Alternative-fuel vehicles cost more than gasoline-powered ones, so the state has spent $3.6 million extra so far without any environmental benefit. The state treasurer's office, which procures the vehicles, said there were only two places, Trenton and Hackensack, to get compressed natural gas.
